com.codename1.rad.components.loginform

Class LoginViewController

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.codename1.rad.controllers.Controller
      • com.codename1.rad.controllers.ViewController
        • com.codename1.rad.components.loginform.LoginViewController
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    ActionListener<ControllerEvent>

    public class LoginViewController
extends ViewController

    A ViewController for the LoginView. Use the setLoginViewDelegate(LoginViewDelegate) to register a delegate to handle common actions.

    Since:
    2.0
    Author:
    shannah

    • Method Detail

      • initControllerActions

        protected void initControllerActions()

        This is run just before Controller.startController(). It can be overridden by subclasses to modify the actions further.

        Overrides:
        initControllerActions in class Controller

      • onStopController

        protected void onStopController()
        Description copied from class: Controller

        A lifecycle method that should be used to cleanup variables and listeners that were setup in the Controller.onStartController() method. Lookups, actions, and the view node are automatically cleared when the controller is stopped, so you don’t have to worry about cleaning up things like that.

        However, you should clean up any variables that you initialized in Controller.onStartController().

        When live-content reloading is enabled in the Codename One simulator, it will trigger Controller.refresh() which stops and starts the controller hierarchy.

        Overrides:
        onStopController in class Controller
        See Also:
        Controller.onStartController(), Controller.refresh()

      • onStartController

        protected void onStartController()
        Description copied from class: Controller

        A lifecycle method that shoudl be used to setup the controller. Use this instead of the constructor as this will allow you to work nicely with live content reloading. When live-content reloading is enabled in the Codename One simulator, it will trigger Controller.refresh() which stops and starts the controller hierarchy.

        When this method is run, you can assume that the parent controller is already in the "started" state.

        Overrides:
        onStartController in class Controller

      • getViewModel

        public LoginViewModel getViewModel()
        Description copied from class: ViewController

        Gets the ViewModel.

        Overrides:

        Returns:

      • createViewNode

        protected ViewNode createViewNode()
        Description copied from class: Controller

        Creates the view node that should be used as the node for the controller’s view. This method should be overridden by subclasses to define the default view node, but this method shouldn’t be called directly. Rather the Controller.getViewNode() method should be called so that the view node is only created once. Controller.getViewNode() will also set the parent node to the view node of the parent controller to more easily benefit from inherited attributes in the UI descriptor hierarchy.

        Overrides:
        createViewNode in class Controller
        Returns:
        A ViewNode

      • createViewModel

        protected LoginViewModel createViewModel()

        Creates the view model to use for the loginview. Subclasses can override this method to provide an alternate LoginViewModel implementation.

        Returns:
